raw_text:
Philippoussis doubt over Open bid
 
 Mark Philippoussis is almost certain to miss the Australian Open after suffering a groin injury during the Hopman Cup loss to the Netherlands.
 
 The 28-year-old suffered two tears to the adductor muscle and was unable to play in the deciding mixed doubles. He is now unlikely to be fit in time for the Australian Open which begins on 17 January in Melbourne. "He has to strengthen it enough to cope with repetitive days of tennis," said Hopman Cup doctor Hamish Osborne. "It would be very unlikely in my opinion for him to do a five-setter once, let alone two days in a row, inside two weeks.
 
 "The injury is more common in Australian Rules football, and a fit footballer would normally take three to four weeks to recover fully although Mark's injury is slightly different." The Australian has suffered a host of injury problems throughout his career but is still holding out slim hope that he can make the event. "It's something I'll have to go by feel. I'll start treatment as soon as possible and try to strengthen it without tearing it any more," he said. "What doesn't kill you makes you stronger. I know I can come back from this and that's all that matters.
 
 - Former world number two Tommy Haas is also a doubt for the Australian Open after picking up a thigh injury playing for Germany in the Hopman Cup. The 26-year-old had treatment on his left thigh while leading Argentine Guillermo Coria 7-5 2-2. He played one more game, but his movement was hampered and he quit.
llama3.2:1b: Philippoussis likely misses Australian Open due to groin injury, which requires strengthening before returning to tennis. Dr Osborne expects him to take three to four weeks to recover fully. Philippoussis has suffered various injuries throughout his career and is holding out hope for a recovery.
llama3.2:3b: Mark Philippoussis may miss Australian Open due to groin injury sustained during Hopman Cup. Injury doctor Hamish Osborne says it's unlikely for him to play five-set matches in two weeks. Philippoussis is holding out hope to recover, saying "what doesn't kill you makes you stronger". Tommy Haas also a doubt for Australian Open after picking up thigh injury during Hopman Cup.
gemma2:2b: Mark Philippoussis is likely to miss the Australian Open due to a groin injury that will require several weeks of recovery.  Former world number two Tommy Haas is also doubtful for the event after suffering a thigh injury during the Hopman Cup.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Philippoussis is expected to miss the Australian Open due to a groin injury, which could put him out of action for two weeks. Haas has been ruled out from the tournament due to an injured left thigh, making both Philippoussis and Haas likely to be eliminated from the event.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Mark Philippoussis is likely to miss the Australian Open due to a groin injury sustained in the Hopman Cup loss to the Netherlands. Doctors suggest he needs significant rest before returning for Melbourne's opening event on January 17th. Philippoussis, who has struggled with numerous injuries throughout his career, remains hopeful but must treat and strengthen his injured area before competing at the tournament.
qwen2.5:3b: Mark Philippoussis is almost certain to miss the Australian Open due to a groin injury sustained during the Hopman Cup. The 28-year-old suffered two tears to the adductor muscle and will likely not be fit in time for the tournament starting January 17th, despite his hope of recovery through treatment and strengthening exercises. Former world number two Tommy Haas is also doubtful for the Australian Open after injuring his thigh playing for Germany in the Hopman Cup.

Mark Philippussis is almost certain to miss the Australian Open after suffering a groin injury during the Hopman Cup loss to the Netherlands. deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text about Mark Philippoussis missing the Australian Open. Let me read through it carefully.

So, Philippoussis suffered a groin injury in the Hopman Cup against Netherlands. He tore two adductor muscles, meaning the muscles around his neck that control breathing and movement. That probably caused him to miss the deciding match in mixed doubles against Novak Djokovic on January 17th in Melbourne.

He's now uncertain about February's Australian Open because he can't play for a couple of weeks. The doctor, Hamish Osborne, thinks it's unlikely for him to participate in more than one set or two days in a row after such a long injury recovery period.

Philippoussis is hoping he'll get better with treatment soon and try again as soon as possible. He says movement issues won't stop him but will slow his progress.

Tommy Haas, another player, had a thigh injury from Germany's Hopman Cup loss to 7-5 2-2 against Guillermo Coria. It seems he can still play for the future but might have some movement problems too.

The main points are Philippoussis' injury, his inability to play the Australian Open, and his recovery status. Haas is a similar story but with different injuries.
</think>

Mark Philippoussis is likely to miss the Australian Open after an injury from the Hopman Cup loss to the Netherlands. He tore two adductor muscles, preventing him from playing in the deciding match against Novak Djokovic on January 17th in Melbourne. He's uncertain about February's event due to potential recovery issues, which could extend his stay in a fit state for up to three weeks. Mark is hopeful he can return soon and try again, though movement problems might hinder progress. Other players like Tommy Haas may also be involved with similar injury concerns.

Philippoussis has suffered various injuries throughout his career but still maintains hope for a comeback at the event. The Australian is expected to miss some time due to his injury, though details regarding the severity remain unknown.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Mark Philippoussis, a 28-year-old former world number two, is highly unlikely to participate in the Australian Open due to a severe groin injury suffered during the Hopman Cup. He sustained tears to his adductor muscle, rendering him unable to play in the deciding mixed doubles match. According to Hopman Cup doctor Hamish Osborne, Philippoussis will need significant time for recovery, likely more than a month, due to the nature of his injury and its impact on repetitive tennis activities. Despite previous career setbacks, he remains cautiously optimistic about his chances.

Former world number two Tommy Haas, 26, is also in doubt for the Australian Open after experiencing a thigh injury while playing for Germany during the Hopman Cup. Haas required treatment on his left thigh mid-match against Argentina's Guillermo Coria, with his movement visibly affected afterward. He opted to withdraw from the contest.
